dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the EU just denied the U.K. a three-month Brexit delay—what does that mean for the October 31 deadline?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the E U just denied the U.K. a three-month Brexit delay-what does that mean for the October thirty one deadline?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit, meaning the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's actually been extended to December 31, 2019 at the latest. Angela Merkel confirmed it on Twitter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's actually been extended to December thirty one, twenty nineteen at the latest. Angela Merkel confirmed it on Twitter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit, meaning the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest. EU Council president Donald Tusk tweeted the confirmation on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and she called it a flextension, which is kind of an interesting term. What exactly does that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and she called it a flextension, which is kind of an interesting term. What exactly does that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU Council president Donald Tusk tweeted the confirmation on Monday. He said: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It means the U.K. could leave even after January 31 if both parliaments ratify a deal before then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It means the U.K. could leave even after January thirty one if both parliaments ratify a deal before then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The flextension means that the U.K. would be allowed to leave the EU before January 31, if the British and European Parliaments ratifiy a deal before then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And this all happened because David Cameron was forced by law to ask for the extension, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And this all happened because David Cameron was forced by law to ask for the extension, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, after a vote on his Brexit bill was blocked, twice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, after his Brexit deal got rejected not once, but twice by U.K. lawmakers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, after his Brexit deal got rejected not once, but twice by U.K. lawmakers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, after a vote on his Brexit bill was blocked, twice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: He really pushed that "do or die" October 31 deadline, didn't he? But now it's clearly not happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He really pushed that do or die October thirty one deadline, didn't he? But now it's clearly not happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson has repeatedly said that he wanted the U.K. to leave the EU on October 31 do or die, but that certainly will not happen now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And now he's pushing for a general election in November because of this whole mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And now he's pushing for a general election in November because of this whole mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move now means Johnson will push for a general election this December, with British lawmakers set to debate the move this afternoon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think an election will actually solve anything, or just create more chaos?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think an election will actually solve anything, or just create more chaos?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it feels like everything just keeps getting delayed and debated without real progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it feels like everything just keeps getting delayed and debated without real progress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the Withdrawal Agreement Bill—lawmakers rejected it last week, but then they approved a short window to try again?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the Withdrawal Agreement Bill-lawmakers rejected it last week, but then they approved a short window to try again?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which sets out the terms of the U.K.s exit from the EU. Johnson then paused the deal after lawmakers rejected a short three-day window in which to debate it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Cameron continued the deal after that, but then he's saying he won't let them debate it if they agree to an election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Cameron continued the deal after that, but then he's saying he won't let them debate it if they agree to an election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for the bill to progress further, Johnson said on Friday that he would allow lawmakers to debate it if they agreed to allowing an election on December 12.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a total stalemate. How are people in the U.K. even keeping up with all this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a total stalemate. How are people in the U.K. even keeping up with all this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, I think a lot of them are just exhausted by the whole thing at this point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, I think a lot of them are just exhausted by the whole thing at this point.

artist_script:
HostA: So the EU just denied the U.K. a three-month Brexit delay—what does that mean for the October 31 deadline?
HostB: Well, it’s actually been extended to December 31, 2019 at the latest. Angela Merkel confirmed it on Twitter.
HostA: Right, and she called it a flextension, which is kind of an interesting term. What exactly does that?
HostB: It means the U.K. could leave even after January 31 if both parliaments ratify a deal before then.
HostA: And this all happened because David Cameron was forced by law to ask for the extension, right?
HostB: Yeah, after his Brexit deal got rejected not once, but twice by U.K. lawmakers.
HostA: He really pushed that "do or die" October 31 deadline, didn’t he? But now it’s clearly not happening.
HostB: Exactly. And now he’s pushing for a general election in November because of this whole mess.
HostA: Do you think an election will actually solve anything, or just create more chaos?
HostB: I mean, it feels like everything just keeps getting delayed and debated without real progress.
HostA: And the Withdrawal Agreement Bill—lawmakers rejected it last week, but then they approved a short window to try again?
HostB: Yeah, Cameron continued the deal after that, but then he’s saying he won’t let them debate it if they agree to an election.
HostA: It’s like a total stalemate. How are people in the U.K. even keeping up with all this?
HostB: Honestly, I think a lot of them are just exhausted by the whole thing at this point.
